body: Note we're talking about the timeout middleware, not shutdown timeout.
So I understand why this has been removed, but will there be support for this in the future? Like a `sidekiq_options :timeout` or something?

No, it will likely never be back.

since I don't actually USE :timeout anywhere. It looks to me like the change to worker.rb at https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/commit/7e094567a585578fad0bfd0c8669efb46643f853 is responsible - was the intent to warn every time the sidekiq_options hash is touched, or only when someone tries to set :timeout?

Warning should be printed only if the timeout option is passed in.

Thats what initially crossed my mind to do. However all parts of the code that could hang (eg. accessing 3rd party server) already have sane timeouts and retries baked in. I'm not sure why is the code hanging. I've only had 1 task per few hundred thousand hang. Maybe its the way how sidekiq is reloaded between redeployments. Anyway, what is the latest version available before :timeout deprecation? Its been doing the job flawlessly for months.

@Netherdrake There's literally no difference in what sidekiq was doing and this:

``` ruby
def perform(...)
  Timeout.timeout(30) do
    some_work
  end
end
```

Please see the changelog for versions.
Oh cool, I didn't know this. Ill wrap the workers in Timeout. Thanks.
@Netherdrake By sane timeouts, are you referring to the sane_timeout gem? https://github.com/jjb/sane_timeout

No, I didn't have worker timeouts, just timeouts on blocking unreliable parts (eg. fetching resources over http). Most of the code had no timeout. I've had about 200,000 works done via Sidekiq using Timeout.timeout as suggested by @mperham  and I'm having 0 issues so far.

Ok, unfortunately it doesnt seem to be timeout issue Im having. I have wrapped the WHOLE `perform` method in `Timeout.timeout` AND within timeout block there is exception handling for what I do, and manual respawn in case of exception. On Timeout exception I let Sidekiq respawn job via :retry => x flag.

But, on 1,2 million jobs, Ive had couple of times happen to me, that jobs just hang forever. They are stuck, and I can't seem to figure out whats wrong.

Its not an exception in perform method. And Timeout does not seem to kill the job and respawn. It just hangs forever.

My code goes like:
sidekiq_options :retry => 5, :backtrace => true

  def perform (message_id)
    Timeout.timeout(30) do
      begin
@Netherdrake I am having a very similar problem. Were you able to find a workaround for you issue? Did you trace it back to Sidekiq or did you find some offensive code being executed by your worker?
